column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0059] FIG. 5 illustrates a second exemplary embodiment of a pair of voltage and current waveforms 510 and 520, respectively, associated with the post start-up method of FIG. 3.
#Text=The voltage waveform 510 is measured by the sensing and current controller 195 between the contact tube 160 and the workpiece 115.
#Text=The current waveform 520 is measured by the sensing and current controller 195 through the wire 140 and workpiece 115.

#Text=[0060] Whenever the distal end of the resistive filler wire 140 is about to lose contact with the workpiece 115, the rate of change of the voltage waveform 510 (i.e., dv/dt) will exceed a predetermined threshold value, indicating that pinch off is about to occur (see the slope at point 511 of the waveform 510).

#Text=As alternatives, a rate of change of current through (di/dt), a rate of change of resistance between (dr/dt), or a rate of change of power through (dp/dt) the filler wire 140 and the workpiece 115 may instead be used to indicate that pinch off is about to occur.
#Text=Such rate of change premonition techniques are well known in the art.
#Text=At that point in time, the sensing and current controller 195 will command the hot wire power supply 170 to turn off (or at least greatly reduce) the flow of current through the wire 140.

#Text=[0061] When the sensing and current controller 195 senses that the distal end of the filler wire 140 again makes good contact with the workpiece 115 after some time interval 530 (e.g., the voltage level drops back to about zero volts at point 512), the sensing and current controller 195 commands the hot wire power supply 170 to apply the flow of heating current (see heating current level 525) through the resistive filler wire 140.
#Text=This process repeats as the energy source 120 and wire 140 move relative to the workpiece 115 and as the wire 140 advances towards the workpiece 115 due to the wire feeder 150.

#Text=In this manner, contact between the distal end of the wire 140 and the workpiece 115 is largely maintained and an arc is prevented from forming between the distal end of the wire 140 and the workpiece 115.
#Text=Since the heating current is not being gradually ramped in this case, certain voltage readings may be ignored as being inadvertent or faulty due to the inductance in the heating circuit.

#Text=[0062] In summary, a method and system to start and use a combination wire feed and energy source system for any of brazing, cladding, building up, filling, and hard-facing overlaying applications are disclosed.
#Text=High intensity energy is applied onto a workpiece to heat the workpiece.
#Text=One or more resistive filler wires are fed toward the workpiece at or just in front of the applied high intensity energy.
#Text=Sensing of when a distal end of the one or more resistive filler wires makes contact with the workpiece at or near the applied high intensity energy is accomplished.

#Text=Electric heating current to the one or more resistive filler wires is controlled based on whether or not the distal end of the one or more resistive filler wires is in contact with the workpiece.
#Text=The applied high intensity energy and the one or more resistive filler wires are moved in a same direction along the workpiece in a fixed relation to each other.
#Text=[0063] In further exemplary embodiments, systems and methods of the present invention are employed for welding or joining operations.
#Text=The embodiments discussed above have focused on the use of filler metals in overlaying operations.
#Text=However, aspects of the present invention can be used in welding and joining applications in which workpieces are joined using welding operations and the use of a filler metal.
#Text=Although directed to overlaying a filler metal, the above described embodiments, systems and methods are similar to that employed in welding operations, described more fully below.
#Text=Therefore, in the following discussions it is understood that the discussions above generally apply, unless otherwise stated.
#Text=Further, the following discussion may include reference to FIGS. 1 through 5.
